chunk_text: Consumption of low-carbohydrate ketogenic diets (low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)s) has been shown to have diverse beneficial effects in promoting health and alleviating pathologic conditions. For example, low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)s exhibit antiepileptic effects,1 promote weight loss in obesity,2 and enhance control of type 2 diabetes mellitus.3 low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)s also reportedly have beneficial effects in patients with autism,4 cardiomyopathy,5 neurodegenerative diseases,1 and cancer.6 The effective and safe use of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)s based on scientific evidence has contributed to both health promotion and disease treatment; however, the molecular mechanisms underlying the beneficial effects of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)s in vivo remain largely unknown.

As a clinical trial demonstrated that restricting carbohydrate intake can reduce intrahepatic triglyceride levels,7 increased research attention has focused on the use of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)s in treating liver steatosis.8 However, children with epilepsy have been shown to develop liver steatosis with long-term consumption of a low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD);9 thus, careful investigation of this effect is needed. A number of studies using rodent models have analyzed the role of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)s in the development of liver steatosis.10–16 Most of these studies used a common low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) for rodents (Bio-Serv F3666),10–13,15,16 with subsequent development of steatosis observed in the liver of the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed mice.

10–12,16 However, surprisingly, we found that the F3666 diet had a dramatic preventative effect on the progression of liver steatosis in juvenile leptin-deficient obese (ob/ob) mice.13 We found that the underlying mechanism involves suppression of de novo triglyceride synthesis.13,16 This low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) also suppresses de novo triglyceride synthesis in C57BL/6J (wild-type) mice that develop liver steatosis.10–12,16 These conflicting results suggest that the beneficial effect of the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) on liver steatosis in ob/ob mice is regulated by an as yet unknown mechanism that is non-functional in wild-type mice.

To clarify the underlying mechanism of these effects, we analyzed several molecular parameters in the liver of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice and found a novel effect of the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) in up-regulating expression of the very-low-density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R)) in the liver. Although this receptor is expressed only minimally in the liver,17 low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) feeding significantly up-regulated very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression in the liver of ob/ob and wild-type mice. Further analyses showed that very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)-triglyceride levels were significantly lower in the serum of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice.

In addition, serum activity of lipoprotein lipase (lipoprotein lipase (LPL)), which mediates triglyceride uptake from very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) into extrahepatic tissues,18 was also down-regulated. In contrast, marked release of very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)-triglycerides was observed in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, whereas lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity was maintained. These alterations in both strains were correlated with the conflicting liver steatosis phenotypes.  The results of our study suggest that the transport of triglycerides via very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) from the liver to extrahepatic tissues is inhibited by low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-induced hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) up-regulation under low lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity, whereas this inhibition of triglyceride transport is rescued under conditions of leptin deficiency.

Animals and dietary studies Dietary studies using female ob/ob and wild-type mice (B6.Cg-Lepob/J and C57BL6J, Charles River Laboratories Japan, Yokohama, Japan) were conducted as reported previously.13 CE-2 (CLEA Japan, Tokyo, Japan), composed of 58.2% carbohydrate, 12.6% fat, and 29.2% protein by calories, was used as regular chow. F3666 (Bio-Serv, Frenchtown, NJ) was used as the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD), which is composed of 1.7% carbohydrate, 93.9% fat, and 4.4% protein by calories. Five-week-old mice were raised on either regular chow or the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) for 7 weeks. During this period, the blood glucose level was monitored at 3:00 p.m. on the first day of every week, and tissue samples were collected at the end of the dietary study. Blood glucose and β-hydroxybutyrate levels were determined using venous blood collected from the tail vein with a Precision Xceed Monitoring System (Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, IL, USA).

The Committee for Experiments Involving Animals of the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology approved all animal experiments.  Gene expression analysis Preparation of total RNA and gene expression analyses were conducted as reported previously.21 Agilent Expression Microarray analysis for gene expression profiling in tissues was conducted by Takara Bio (Shiga, Japan). The resulting microarray data were analyzed using the Aqua microarray viewer and Aqua t test (Takara Bio) and deposited in the GEO under accession number GSE115342. Relative quantification of target gene expression by real-time PCR was performed using a Light Cycler® 480 II system (Roche, Penzberg, Germany) with the following Vldlr gene-specific primers: forward, 5′-gcccgttctactcagtgtatcc-3′; reverse, 5′-gaactcatctgcactacatgttatgtt-3′ (accession number of the Vldlr gene: NM_013703, GenBank).

Reactions were performed using a KAPA SYBR® FAST qPCR Kit (KAPA Biosystems, Wilmington, MA) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. As it is stably expressed in the liver,21 Eef1a1 was chosen as a housekeeping gene and used as the internal reference for subsequent real-time PCR analyses.  Immunoblot analysis Protein extraction and immunoblot analyses were conducted according to a previously reported method16,31 using an anti-very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) antibody (AF2258; Bio-Techne, Minneapolis, MN, USA).  Lipoprotein analysis The triglyceride and cholesterol profiles of serum lipoproteins were determined using a high-sensitivity lipoprotein profiling system employing high-performance liquid chromatography (Skylight Biotech Inc., Akita, Japan), as reported previously.

13  Measurement of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity Serum lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity (units ml−1) was measured using an lipoprotein lipase (LPL) Activity Assay Kit (Cell Biolabs, Inc., San Diego, CA, USA) according to the manufacturer’s instructions.  Analysis of choline-containing phospholipids in the F3666 low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) and serum The content of choline-containing phospholipids was determined using a Phosphatidylcholine Assay Kit (Phospholipids C, FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corp., Osaka, Japan) according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

After determination of variance using the F test, statistical significance was evaluated using the two-tailed Student’s t test, with statistical significance defined as follows: *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01, and ***P < 0.001. Characterization of liver phenotypes in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed mice Wild-type and ob/ob mice of the inbred strain C57BL/6J were used in this study and fed the Bio-Serv F3666 low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD). F3666 is a very-low-carbohydrate, low-protein, high-fat ketogenic diet developed to induce efficient production of ketone bodies in rodents.19 In ob/ob mutant mice fed a diet of regular chow, hyperglycemia typically develops at ~10 weeks of age.20 Our initial goal was to reverse this phenotype via feeding mice the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) and analyze the diet’s effects on tissues at the molecular level. The mice were fed the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) over the period 5–12 weeks of age in the dietary experiment.13 We found that the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) feeding effectively reversed the hyperglycemic phenotype in female ob/ob mice during this period and therefore employed these conditions in subsequent experiments.

13 The average blood glucose levels during the experimental period were as follows: chow-fed ob/ob mice, 194.30 ± 43.78 mg dl−1; low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, 106.96 ± 26.41 mg dl−1; chow-fed wild-type mice, 154.08 ± 20.55 mg dl−1; and low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, 114.30 ± 15.05 mg dl−1. Production of ketone bodies (β-hydroxybutyrate) was observed in both the ob/ob and wild-type mice.13,16,21  Figure 1a shows the morphology of the liver after 7 weeks of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) feeding. In ob/ob mice, regular chow promoted significant steatosis associated with enlargement of the liver (left panel). Liver weight and total amount of triglycerides increased by more than 2-fold compared to values prior to the start of the experiment (Fig. 1b). The low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) is known to inhibit the progression of liver steatosis in ob/ob mice.

13 Compared to chow-fed mice, the liver weight and total amount of triglycerides decreased by at least 70% in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed mice (Fig. 1b). The average triglycerides (mg) to liver weight (g) ratios were as follows: chow-fed ob/ob mice, 65.75 ± 24.7 mg g−1; and low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, 48.79 ± 16.93 mg g−1. In contrast, the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) strongly promoted steatosis in wild-type mice. In low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, the total amount of triglycerides in the liver has been shown to increase by more than 3-fold.16 Although liver weight remained unchanged in the present study, the organ became discolored as a result of excessive triglyceride accumulation (Fig. 1a, right panel). The average triglycerides (mg) to liver weight (g) ratios were as follows: chow-fed wild-type mice, 19.17 ± 5.68 mg g−1; and low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, 63.65 ± 16.44 mg g−1.

In both strains, body weight gain and diet intake (kcal per day) were similar in the chow- and low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed groups during the experimental period.13,16 Although low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) feeding improved the steatosis associated with enlargement of the liver, low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice became obese to the same degree as chow-fed ob/ob mice.13 The average final body weights were as follows: chow-fed ob/ob mice, 53.16 ± 2.45 g; low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, 52.47 ± 3.45 g; chow-fed wild-type mice, 19.16 ± 1.79 g; and low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, 17.87 ± 2.02 g. The average caloric intake during the experimental period was as follows: chow-fed ob/ob mice, 18.56 ± 0.4 kcal per day; low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, 17.27 ± 2.43 kcal per day; chow-fed wild-type mice, 10.48 ± 0.

46 kcal per day; and low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, 10.41 ± 1.5 kcal per day.Fig. 1 Effect of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) feeding on liver phenotypes. a Morphology of the liver after 7 weeks of feeding. b Wet weight (n = 11–13) and total triglyceride levels (n = 5–6) in the liver. c Real-time PCR analysis of expression of the Vldlr gene (n = 6). The relative expression level is shown as the ratio relative to expression of the internal standard (Eef1a1). Statistical significance was assessed using the two-tailed Student’s t test. *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01, ***P < 0.001, chow-fed vs. low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed. Black squares and bars, regular chow-fed mice; gray squares and bars, low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed mice.

Mean ± SD    low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) effect on hepatic gene expression A gene expression microarray analysis was conducted to elucidate the molecular mechanism underlying the improvement of liver steatosis in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice. Data for all genes detected as specific signals were compared with data for mice fed the regular chow (n = 3) and deposited in the NCBI Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO; accession number GSE115342). The overall features of the results have been published elsewhere.21  A novel result observed in the present study was significant up-regulation of the Vldlr gene, which encodes the very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R). The microarray analysis revealed significant up-regulation (log2 ratio [low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)/chow] of +1.78; P < 0.05) of Vldlr, which was confirmed in validation experiments using real-time PCR (Fig. 1c) with a greater number of samples (n = 6).

No apparent effects on other factors associated with very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) metabolism were observed in this experiment.  Effect of the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) on induction of very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) in the liver As very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) regulates the release of triglycerides from the liver to the blood stream,18 we expected that up-regulation of Vldlr would correlate with the liver phenotype in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed mice. Immunoblot analysis showed that very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R), which is not normally expressed in the liver,17,22 was detected in the liver of mice fed the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) (Fig. 2). However, the induction of very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression was observed in both ob/ob (Fig. 2a) and wild-type (Fig.

2b) mice, indicating that this effect is not specific to ob/ob mice. Although individual differences were observed, further statistical analyses indicated that the effect was associated with the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) (Fig. 2c). The statistical analyses also revealed that the level of very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice was higher than that in ob/ob mice (P < 0.01).Fig. 2 Immunoblot analysis of very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) in the liver. Representative images of immunoblotting of very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) in the liver of individual ob/ob a or wild-type b mice (n = 6). Actin is shown as an internal standard.

Mean ± SD    Characterization of lipid content of lipoproteins and lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in serum To clarify the effect of hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) on lipoprotein dynamics, we subsequently analyzed the lipid content of serum lipoproteins (Table 1). We found that levels of very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)-triglycerides were markedly lower in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, but unchanged in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice.

In contrast, very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)-cholesterol levels were unchanged in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, but significantly lower in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice. These results indicate that the release of very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) from the liver to the blood stream is not impaired in either low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed mouse strain; rather, only very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)-mediated triglyceride release is specifically inhibited in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice. The increase in LDL-cholesterol levels in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice also supports the normal release of very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) from the liver in these mice.

In low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, the cholesterol content of the very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) fraction was considerably lower than the triglyceride content, indicating that triglyceride-rich very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) was generated in these mice. Furthermore, LDL-triglyceride levels were significantly higher in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, but unchanged in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, which indicates a difference between ob/ob and wild-type mice in terms of conversion from very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)-triglycerides to LDL-triglycerides. As this process is mediated by lipoprotein lipase (LPL),18 we preliminarily measured the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) in the serum and found a significant decrease only in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice (Supplementary Fig. S1).

In contrast, serum lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity was the same in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)- and regular chow-fed ob/ob mice, indicating that the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-associated decrease in serum lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity is specific to wild-type mice. Statistical analyses also revealed that lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in chow-fed ob/ob mice was lower than that in chow-fed wild-type mice (P < 0.01). However, lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice was higher than that in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice (P < 0.05).Table 1 Serum lipoprotein lipid content  	Strain	 	 ob/ob 		Wild type		 Diet	Chow	low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)	Chow	low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)	 Parameters	  Triglyceride (mmol l−1)	   Total	1.23 ± 0.22	1.47 ± 0.30	1.30 ± 0.20	0.18 ± 0.03**	   CM	0.31 ± 0.06	0.08 ± 0.02*	0.14 ± 0.03	0.02 ± 0.

A novel effect of the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) on induction of very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression was found in the liver, where this receptor is not normally expressed. Previous studies reported that the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor α agonist fenofibrate promotes not only hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression22 but also steatosis,23 which is in agreement with the phenotype of the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice in the present study. The induction of hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression by fenofibrate or over-expression of very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) decreases triglyceride-rich very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) levels via triglyceride clearance by the liver,22,24 which can promote the development of liver steatosis.

F3666 is a commonly used low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) for rodents, and several recent studies have examined the effects of the low amounts of choline and protein in this diet.14,15 A lack of sufficient choline is associated with the development of steatosis in the liver,14,15,25 which impairs hepatic triglyceride secretion due to an absence of phosphatidylcholine synthesis.25 Choline supplementation can improve this pathologic condition.14,15 The low protein content of the F3666 diet increases the expression of several genes in the liver, but this effect is attenuated by methionine supplementation.15 These observations suggest that the low choline and protein content of the F3666 diet also played a role in the effects observed in our model. However, in ob/ob mice in our model, the F3666 diet prevented the progression of liver steatosis observed in chow-fed ob/ob mice (Fig. 1).

Furthermore, the F3666 diet used in our study contained an abundance of choline-containing phospholipids (phosphatidylcholines and sphingomyelins, 5.8 ± 0.2 g kg−1), and serum levels of choline-containing phospholipids in F3666-fed mice were also significantly higher than the levels in chow-fed mice (Supplementary Fig. S2). These results indicate that choline was supplied to peripheral tissues in sufficient amounts in the mice using this study, and therefore, choline levels had a minimal effect on development of steatosis.  We also observed very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression in the liver of low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, in which the hyperphagic phenotype can compensate for the low protein content of the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD).

This result indicates that the low protein content of the diet is not associated with increased very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression. As the low protein content of the F3666 diet plays an important role in the generation of ketone bodies in rodents,19 we conclude that the low-carbohydrate and high-fat/ketogenic properties of the low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) induce hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression.  Based on the results of our present and previous studies,13,16 Fig. 3 illustrates the dynamics and metabolism of very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed mice and presents a working hypothesis of how very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) and lipoprotein lipase (LPL) affect very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)-triglyceride kinetics.

In low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice, induction of hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression and decreased serum lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity inhibit the transport of triglycerides by very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) from the liver to extrahepatic tissues, ultimately promoting steatosis (Fig. 3b). low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-induced very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression promotes triglyceride clearance from very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) in the liver and the progression of liver steatosis. As lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity is necessary for the clearance of triglycerides from very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) in peripheral tissues,18 decreased lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity slows triglyceride transport from the liver to peripheral tissues and promotes the development of liver steatosis.

In low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice, the generation of triglyceride-rich very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) and maintained lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity promote the transport of triglycerides from the liver to extrahepatic tissues, ultimately leading to improvement of steatosis (Fig. 3d). Maintained lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity promotes the clearance of triglycerides from very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) in peripheral tissues, which can accelerate triglyceride transport from the liver to peripheral tissues and contribute to the improvement of liver steatosis. low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-induced very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression has a minimal effect on triglyceride-rich very low density lipoprotein (VLDL), which is specifically generated in the ob/ob strain.

low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice became obese to the same degree as chow-fed ob/ob mice, in agreement with the observed effective transport of very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)-triglycerides from the liver to extrahepatic tissues in these mice.Fig. 3 Schematic illustrations of very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) dynamics and metabolism in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed mice. Overview of very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) dynamics and metabolism in chow-fed wild-type a, low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed wild-type mice b, chow-fed ob/ob mice c, and low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice d. The size and number of objects are drawn to reflect the experimental results.

The working hypothesis regarding the effect of hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) on very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) is as follows: (i) in wild-type mice, low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) induces hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression, which inhibits triglyceride (TG) secretion via very low density lipoprotein (VLDL); (ii) in ob/ob mice, low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) induces hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression, whereas the very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) does not function for TG-rich very low density lipoprotein (VLDL), which is specifically generated in the ob/ob strain.

Ch, cholesterol; FA, fatty acid    In ob/ob mice, low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD) feeding induces the production of triglyceride-rich very low density lipoprotein (VLDL), which has a long plasma residence time due to slow catabolism.26,27 This property indicates that triglyceride-rich very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) is readily delivered to extrahepatic tissues even though very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression is induced in the liver. As an absence of hepatic leptin signaling leads to elevated triglyceride levels in very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) particles,28 the production of triglyceride-rich very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) is likely associated with leptin deficiency in ob/ob mice.29 The maintenance of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-fed ob/ob mice could also accelerate the release of triglycerides to extrahepatic tissues.

As leptin regulates lipoprotein lipase (LPL) production and activity in the tissues,30 maintenance of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity is also likely associated with leptin deficiency in ob/ob mice.29  Based on these observations, we conclude that the transport of triglycerides via very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) from the liver to extrahepatic tissues is inhibited by low carbohydrate ketogenic diet (LCKD)-induced hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R) expression under conditions of low lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity. As this inhibition of triglyceride transport is rescued in leptin-deficient mice, regulating very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) metabolism by hepatic very low density lipoprotein receptor (very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)R), lipoprotein lipase (LPL), and leptin may represent a new therapeutic strategy for preventing diet-induced liver steatosis.
